summary: This document is a Bureau of Prisons psychological services record for Jeffrey Epstein, covering his intake, suicide risk assessments, and psychological observations from his arrival at MCC New York on July 6, 2019, to his death on August 10, 2019. It details his mental health evaluations, his placement and removal from suicide watch/psychological observation, an incident on July 23 where a string was found around his neck, and his interactions with prison psychologists and his cellmate. This document contains Bureau of Prisons psychological service notes and suicide risk assessments for inmate Jeffrey Epstein, conducted on July 8-10, 2019, while he was held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York (NYM). The assessments were triggered by his high-profile case and a court proceeding, but clinicians found him at low acute suicide risk with numerous protective factors. This document contains a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology service notes for inmate Jeffrey Epstein from July 9-24, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It details initial suicide risk assessments, daily clinical contacts, and a significant event on July 23 where Epstein was found with a string around his neck and placed on suicide watch. The notes show Epstein's psychological state, his complaints about jail conditions, and his interactions with staff. This document is a series of Bureau of Prisons psychology reports detailing Jeffrey Epstein's mental health status and interviews following his placement on suicide watch after an incident in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on July 23, 2019. The reports document his claims of memory loss regarding neck injuries, his denial of suicidality, his complaints about SHU conditions, and his eventual step-down to psychological observation. This document contains a Bureau of Prisons memorandum dated August 10, 2019, summarizing psychological contacts with Jeffrey Epstein from July 8 to August 8, 2019, at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. It details his placement on and removal from suicide watch, an incident where he was found with a string around his neck, and his psychological assessments. The document also includes the full text of the BOP's Suicide Prevention Program policy statement from 2007. This document is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) policy manual (P5324.08) detailing the procedures for the Suicide Prevention Program. It outlines the roles and responsibilities of the Program Coordinator, conditions for suicide watch, use of inmate observers, transfer protocols, and procedures for analyzing inmate suicides. It includes attachments with a guide for psychological reconstruction of a suicide and a sample information sheet for staff. This document is a collection of Bureau of Prisons administrative records, primarily from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC). It includes suicide prevention protocols, a record of a 2007 mock suicide training exercise, and numerous logs related to Jeffrey Epstein's suicide watch and inmate status in July 2019. It also contains daily running board counts for the MCC from July 2019. This document is a series of running board logs from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York, detailing inmate counts, movements, and visits over several days in late July and early August 2019. The logs show the transfer of inmate Jeffrey Epstein (listed as 'Epstein HA') to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) on July 30, 2019, and record the inmate population counts before and after his death.

events.title: Epstein arrives at MCC NY
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrives at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, New York and is placed in General Population (GP).

events.title: Initial psychological intake
events.description: Dr. Schlessinger conducts an intake screening. Epstein denies any mental health history, symptoms, or suicidality. He is assigned Care Level 1.

events.title: String found around Epstein's neck
events.description: Epstein is placed on Suicide Watch after a string is found loosely hanging around his neck. He claims not to remember the event and initially told a staff member his cellmate tried to kill him.

events.title: Post-Suicide Watch report
events.description: Dr. DiMisa interviews Epstein, who expresses fear of his previous cellmate, reports the cellmate called him a pedophile, and adamantly denies suicidality.

events.title: Removed from psychological observation
events.description: Dr. Imeri discontinues Epstein's psychological observation status. He is taken off at 8:15 a.m. and later moved to the SHU.

events.title: Epstein found dead
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is found unresponsive and hanging in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at 6:30 a.m., ten days after removal from constant observation.

events.title: Court Proceeding and Precautionary Observation
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein attended a court proceeding. Upon his return to the correctional facility in the evening, due to identified risk factors, he was placed on precautionary psychological observation status.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Dr. Elissa Miller conducted a formal suicide risk assessment on Jeffrey Epstein. The assessment concluded his overall acute suicide risk was low and chronic risk was absent.

events.title: Consultation on Epstein's Risk Factors
events.description: Dr. Elissa Miller consulted with Dr. Robert Nagle from the Central Office regarding inmate Epstein's various risk factors for suicidality.

events.title: Initial Suicide Risk Assessment
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is seen for a precautionary suicide risk assessment after returning from court. He denies any history of mental health issues, suicidality, or substance abuse. He is classified as psychologically stable.

events.title: Clinical Contact and Complaints
events.description: Epstein is seen for a psychological observation contact. He voices numerous complaints about jail conditions (housing, uniform, property) and discusses his upcoming bail hearing. He denies any suicidality.

events.title: Epstein Found with String Around Neck
events.description: At about 2 AM, Epstein is placed on Suicide Watch after being found in his SHU cell with a string loosely hanging around his neck. It is unclear if he placed it there himself. He later tells staff his cellmate tried to kill him.

events.title: Suicide Risk Assessment After Incident
events.description: Psychologist Darlene Imeri conducts a suicide risk assessment. Epstein claims not to remember the incident, has a mark on his neck, and reports a sore throat. His overall acute suicide risk is assessed as 'Moderate' and he remains on Suicide Watch.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein is placed on suicide watch following an incident in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) where he sustained a significant scar around his neck. He claims no memory of the event.

events.title: Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein is stepped down from suicide watch to psychological observation after psychological evaluation. He continues to deny suicidal ideation and memory of the neck injury incident.

events.title: Daily Psychological Observations
events.description: A series of daily clinical contacts and psychological observations of Epstein are conducted by prison psychologists Imeri, DiMisa, and Miller while he is on psychological observation.

events.title: Epstein intake and initial suicide watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrives at MCC NY and is seen for an intake screening. The Chief Psychologist speaks with Central Office and it is determined he should be placed on suicide watch due to increased risk factors.

events.title: First suicide risk assessment
events.description: Epstein is seen for a suicide risk assessment, denies any suicidal ideation, and is removed from suicide watch and placed on psychology observation.

events.title: Found with string around neck
events.description: At approximately 2am, the on-call psychologist is contacted because Epstein was found with a string hanging around his neck and is placed on suicide watch. He is assessed at 9am.

events.title: Removed from suicide watch after neck incident
events.description: Epstein is removed from suicide watch and placed on psychology observation. A scar around his neck is observed. He denies knowing what happened.

events.title: Court note on 'suicidal tendencies'
events.description: Epstein returns from court with a note from the court indicating 'suicidal tendencies.' He is assessed again and denies being suicidal.

events.title: Mock Suicide Emergency Training
events.description: A training exercise conducted in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at 5:30 a.m. to simulate a response to a hanging in a cell. Staff discussed the response and a recommendation was made to change key storage.

events.title: Epstein Not Medically Cleared
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's inmate history shows he was marked 'NOT MEDICALLY CLEARED' starting on this date.

events.title: Epstein Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was removed from suicide watch at 8:45 AM.

events.title: Epstein transferred to Special Housing Unit (SHU)
events.description: The running board log for July 30, 2019, shows inmate Jeffrey Epstein (listed as 'Epstein HA') was moved to the Special Housing Unit (SHU), noted as 'ZA 12:21'. This occurred on the day he was found unresponsive in his cell.

events.title: Daily inmate population counts at MCC
events.description: The logs record the daily starting and post-check inmate counts at the Metropolitan Correctional Center, showing fluctuations in the total population (e.g., from 771 to 754) over this period.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein underwent multiple psychological evaluations in July-August 2019, consistently denying any history of mental health issues, suicidal thoughts, or intent.
On July 23, 2019, Epstein was placed on Suicide Watch after a string was found loosely around his neck; he had no memory of the event and initially told a staff member his cellmate tried to kill him.
Epstein expressed fear of a previous cellmate who had called him a pedophile and was agitated, but later reported getting along with a subsequent cellmate.
Epstein was removed from psychological observation status on July 30, 2019, and was housed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU).
Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive and hanging in his SHU cell on the morning of August 10, 2019, ten days after being taken off constant observation.

On July 8-9, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was placed on precautionary psychological observation due to identified risk factors for suicidality, including his high-profile case, sex offense charges, and a recent court proceeding.

Clinical assessments by Chief Psychologist Elissa Miller found Epstein denied any past or present suicidal ideation, had no mental health history, and was future-oriented. He was assessed as having a low acute suicide risk.
Epstein reported his only family was a brother with whom he did not have a close relationship, which was listed as a static risk factor.
Epstein stated he had a bail hearing scheduled for the Monday following the assessment (July 8, 2019 was a Monday, so likely July 15) and believed he would be released.

The documents reveal institutional awareness of Epstein's risk profile and the implementation of specific monitoring protocols, including instructions for staff to notify psychology immediately upon his return from court.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his SHU cell with a string loosely tied around his neck, leading to his placement on Suicide Watch.
Epstein told staff watching him that his cellmate tried to kill him, a statement he did not repeat to the assessing psychologist, Dr. Imeri.

Psychological assessments from July 9-23 consistently noted Epstein denied any history of mental health issues, suicidality, or substance abuse, and was found psychologically stable prior to the July 23 incident.
Epstein voiced numerous complaints about his incarceration conditions, including his housing, orange jumpsuit, lack of property, and desire for a kosher diet.

The suicide risk assessment on July 23 concluded Epstein's overall acute suicide risk was 'Moderate' due to the unclear nature of the string incident, despite his denial of suicidal intent and identified protective factors.
Jeffrey Epstein was placed on suicide watch on July 23, 2019, after being found with a significant, scabbing scar around his neck, an incident for which he repeatedly claimed to have no memory.

Psychological assessments identified static risk factors including 'High Profile Crime', 'Lack of family connections', and 'Sex offender status', and dynamic factors like 'Current physical pain' and 'Fear for own safety'.
Epstein adamantly and consistently denied any current or past suicidal ideation, intent, or plans, stating he was invested in his legal case and had a 'wonderful life' to return to.
Epstein expressed fear about returning to the SHU, citing safety concerns, noise preventing sleep, the presence of MS-13 gang members, and his agitated former cellmate who called him a 'pedophile'.

The Bureau of Prisons psychology staff, despite Epstein's denials, maintained him on psychological observation 'in an abundance of caution' due to the vague nature of the neck injury incident and his adjustment difficulties.
On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with a string hanging around his neck, leading to his placement on suicide watch.

Epstein repeatedly denied suicidal ideation, intention, or plan during psychological assessments from July to August 2019, citing his desire to fight his case and that suicide was against his religion.

A note from the court on August 1, 2019, indicated Epstein had 'suicidal tendencies,' but a subsequent BOP risk assessment concluded his protective factors outweighed his risk factors and he was not placed on watch.

The document includes the detailed BOP Suicide Prevention Program policy (P5324.08), outlining procedures for identifying and managing potentially suicidal inmates, including mandatory mock emergency drills.
Epstein expressed multiple complaints about his conditions, including wearing an orange jumpsuit, not receiving medication, lack of water during attorney visits, and noise in the SHU.
This is a formal BOP policy (P5324.08) establishing comprehensive procedures for suicide prevention, watch, and post-incident review within federal prisons.
The policy mandates that only the Warden may authorize the use of inmate observers (companions) for suicide watch, and they must be carefully selected, trained, and supervised.
The document emphasizes that a suicide watch may only be terminated after a face-to-face evaluation by the Program Coordinator, who has sole authority to remove an inmate from watch.
In the event of an inmate suicide, the policy requires treating the scene as a crime scene and mandates a psychological reconstruction report and review by a Special Review Committee.
The policy includes federal regulations (28 CFR 552.40-552.42) that legally bind BOP staff to the described suicide prevention program practices.
